IRM 25.25.3.3(2) - Added a Note to advise, due to the implementation of systemic veriﬁcation, TEs should only be calling an employer as directed by IRM 25.25.3.9. IPU 22U0112 issued
IRM 25.25.3.13(3) a- Added a reminder for TEs to make sure to comply with the Taxpayer First Act before contacting an employer. IPU 22U0112 issued 01-14-2022.
IRM 25.25.3 dated October 07, 2021 (effective November 15, 2021) is superseded. This IRM also incorporates IPU 22U0112 issued 01-14-2022.
Campus employees in Return Integrity Veriﬁcation Operations
Director, Return Integrity Veriﬁcation Program Management Wage and Investment Division
Protection Veriﬁcation Procedures for Individual File Returns

) Purpose and Program Goals: This IRM section provides guidance for Integrity Veriﬁcation Operations (RIVO) employees when verifying Scope and master ﬁle returns in the Electronic Fraud Detection System (EFDS) for possible identity theft and false income and withholding. Individual master returns are scored through the Dependent Database (DDb) or through the Return Review Program (RRP) system. These scoring processes identify picious returns meeting the scoring criteria for screening by RIVO (
) Audience; The audience intended in this IRM is RIVO employees. (
) Policy Owner; The Return Integrity Veriﬁcation Program Management is the policy owner of this program. (
) Program Owner; RIVPM is the program office responsible for oversight this program. (
) Primary Stakeholders; The primary stakeholders are Return Integrity tion Operation (RIVO), and organizations that collaborate with RIVO. (
) Program Goals; Program goals for the program are in the Operation lines as well as IRM
, Return Integrity & Veriﬁcation Operation Guide. (

) Return Integrity Veriﬁcation Program Management (RIVPM) strengthens integrity of the tax system by: • Protecting the public interest by improving IRS’s ability to detect and prevent improper refunds • Serving the public interest by taking actions fairly and appropriately identify, evaluate and prevent the issuance of improper refunds • Helping taxpayers understand the refundable tax credits for which are eligible (

) The program has reports such; as the Return Integrity Veriﬁcation (RIVO) Monthly Performance Comparison Report, to track the inventory, Management including receipts and closures. Additional report guidance is found in IRM Review
, Return Integrity & Veriﬁcation Operation Managers Guide. (

) The Embedded Quality review program is in place to review all processes ensure accuracy and effectiveness of the program. Goals, measures, and operating guidelines are listed in the yearly Operation Guidelines and in

, Embedded Quality (EQ) Program for Accounts Management, Compliance, Field Assistance, Tax Exempt/Government Entities, Return Integrity and Compliance Services (RICS), and Electronic Products and Services Support. (

, Policy Statement

Stakeholders; The primary stakeholders are Return Integrity Veriﬁca- Operation (RIVO), and organizations that collaborate with RIVO.
Program Goals; Program goals for the program are in the Operation Guide- lines as well as IRM 1.4.10, Return Integrity & Veriﬁcation Operation Managers
Return Integrity Veriﬁcation Program Management (RIVPM) strengthens the integrity of the tax system by:

Protecting the public interest by improving IRS’s ability to detect and prevent improper refunds Serving the public interest by taking actions fairly and appropriately to identify, evaluate and prevent the issuance of improper refunds Helping taxpayers understand the refundable tax credits for which they are eligible

) The Director of RIVPM is responsible for the policy related to this IRM. (
) The Chief of the RIVPM Policy & Analysis is responsible for ensuring this is timely submitted to publishing each year. (
) More information can be found in IRM
, Return Integrity and ance Services. (

, Acronyms. (

) IDRS restricted access accounts are accounts where a user must request special permissions to access the account through IDRS. Follow IRM
, Authorized IDRS Access. (
) The IRS adopted the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in June
are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accordance with rights. See IRC §
), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights. For additional information about the TBOR, the IRS outlines the Taxpayer Bill of Rights, Taxpayer Bill of Rights. (

) Veriﬁcation of income documents (IDOC(s)) attached to Individual Master (IMF) returns is critical to stopping questionable refunds. The IRS is notify a taxpayer in advance that a third party may be contacted to help resolve their account. For further information concerning third-party see IRM
, Notiﬁcation of Third Party Contact. (
) Observe the Taxpayer Bill of Rights as spelled out in Publication
, Your as a Taxpayer, particularly with respect to conﬁdentiality and privacy when ducting research and/or contact with third parties to obtain income Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Protection Veriﬁcation Procedures for Individual File Returns 25.25.3

When an IDOC is sent to Veriﬁcation, Workload Management System (WMS) will place the IDOC in “Suspense”. The IDOCs can be viewed but no action can be taken on the IDOC during the suspense period. Generally, IDOC(s) may include:
Note: The list is not all inclusive.
Form W-
, Wage and Tax Statement Form W-
G, Certain Gambling Winnings Form
-R, Distributions From Pensions, Annuities, Retirement or Proﬁt-Sharing Plans, IRAs, Insurance Contracts, etc. Form
, Substitute for Form W-
, Wage and Tax Statement or Form
R, Distribution From Pensions, Annuities, Retirement or Proﬁt- Sharing Plans, IRAs
Exception: You may receive a Form

, Operations Assistance Request (OAR), from Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS). The request may that TAS has informed the taxpayer the employer will be contacted to verify the income document and the taxpayer has agreed to the employer contact. If all the information is on the OAR, you can verify the income with the employer without the suspension time. Add a to Electronic Fraud Detection System (EFDS): OAR Received agrees to employer contact. (

) There are various methods used to verify IDOCs: • Phone Veriﬁcation - the request is made by a call Note: RIVO does not call employers unless directed by IRM Manual Veriﬁcation Procedures. • Command Code (CC) IRPTR Veriﬁcation - veriﬁcation performed CC IRPTR data information (

) By law, employers are not required to provide IRS employees information unless served with a summons or subpoena. Summonses are issued by revenue officers, revenue agents, and special agents. Therefore, it is critical that proper telephone techniques are developed to the highest degree of effi- ciency and tact.
Exception: You may receive a Form

, Operations Assistance Request (OAR), from Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS). The request may state, that TAS has informed the taxpayer the employer will be contacted to verify the income document and the taxpayer has agreed to the employer contact. If all the information is on the OAR, you can verify the income with the employer without the suspension time. Add a note to Electronic Fraud Detection System (EFDS): OAR Received taxpayer agrees to employer contact.

By law, employers are not required to provide IRS employees information unless served with a summons or subpoena. Summonses are issued by revenue officers, revenue agents, and special agents. Therefore, it is critical that proper telephone techniques are developed to the highest degree of effi
ciency and tact.
Note: See IRM
, Communication Skills, and IRM
, Authorized and Unauthorized Disclosures, , for additional information. (

) Return Integrity Veriﬁcation Operations (RIVO) has agreed to verify that Criminal Investigation (CI) has added to CE regardless of tolerance and refund lost. CI will input an EFDS note - “CI POST REFUND” when sending IDOCs on post refund returns to “VERIFY”. All IDOCs sent to veriﬁcation must be veriﬁed. (

) The Workload Management System (WMS) is used to access the application Contact Employer (CE) and is used to manage the income veriﬁcation at both a National and Local level. The employee will log into WMS and access CE from the main menu bar. (
) The purpose of CE is to automate the process of verifying suspicious income documents (IDOCs) that are submitted with potentially false returns. IDOCs may include, Form W-
, Wage and Tax Statement, Form W-
G, Certain Gambling Winnings, and Form

-R, Distributions From Pensions, Retirement or Proﬁt-Sharing Plans, IRAs, Insurance Contracts, etc. Tax Examiners (TE) need to be conscious of the IDOC type when making a phone call to the employer. Note: RIVO does not call employers unless directed to IRM
, Manual Veriﬁcation Procedures. (

) When a return is sent for veriﬁcation, the employer may have or may need a mode of contact (MOC) assigned in CE. A MOC identiﬁes the way an will be contacted to verify income and withholding information for a question- able IDOC. (

) Documentation or remarks in the Electronic Fraud Detection System (EFDS) essential for proper movement, treatment and resolution. Remarks should be brief and speciﬁc to the issue or case or as directed by the IRM. (

) Command Code (CC) IRPTR will be used to verify all prior year returns and current year returns when CC IRPTR data is available or considered fully loaded. For returns containing an Individual Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (ITIN) for the primary and/or secondary, see IRM
, Updating Indi- vidual Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (ITIN) Income Documents (IDOCs). Use CC IRPTR ﬁrst for all types of veriﬁcation each ﬁling season per leadership direction. (
) The Income Veriﬁcation Table is used to verify income using CC IRPTR. Use the table below only if CC IRPTR data is available for the tax year:

Protection Veriﬁcation Procedures for Individual File Returns 25.25.3
The Mode of Contact is marked as Suspicious.

Telephone veriﬁcation inventory is maintained in contact employer (CE) by the “Stop Date” of the refund. Inventory is retrieved by running a Discoverer Query using the date the refund was held to ensure the cases are worked in received date order. Return Integrity Veriﬁcation Operations (RIVO) employees will receive the inventory by selecting “Next EIN” in CE. Telephone veriﬁcation is used to verify questionable income documents (IDOC) such as Form W-
, Form
, and Form
, when the information is not
) All IRS employees working tax related matters must provide their name and badge identiﬁcation number when making phone calls, see IRM
, munication Skills, for details. (
) If an answering machine or voice mail is reached when attempting to contact the employer, see IRM
, IRS Employee Contact--Restructuring and Reform Act (RRA) Section

(a), for additional guidance. If you are reason- ably sure you have reached the correct employer, it is acceptable to provide your name, badge number, a telephone call back number, the purpose of your call, the company you are trying to reach, and that you are with the IRS. Do not include or provide the company EIN or any taxpayer information in the message. (
) All return calls from the employer left on the IRS voice mail must be retrieved on a daily workday basis. (
) If the MOC is “No Selection” or the contact information (phone or fax number) is not found in CE, perform additional research to locate the employer’s contact information. See Exhibit

, Research Check Sheet. Always review “Return Notes” for additional information including the tax year you need to verify. If the contact information is located, the employer must be called to establish a preferred MOC.
If an answering machine or voice mail is reached when attempting to contact the employer, see IRM
, IRS Employee Contact--Restructuring and Reform Act (RRA) Section

(a), for additional guidance. If you are reason- ably sure you have reached the correct employer, it is acceptable to provide your name, badge number, a telephone call back number, the purpose of your call, the company you are trying to reach, and that you are with the IRS. Do not include or provide the company EIN or any taxpayer information in the message.

If an answering machine or voice mail is reached when attempting to contact the employer, see IRM 3.13.5.3.1, IRS Employee Contact--Restructuring and Reform Act (RRA) Section 3705(a), for additional guidance. If you are reason- ably sure you have reached the correct employer, it is acceptable to provide your name, badge number, a telephone call back number, the purpose of call, the company you are trying to reach, and that you are with the IRS. Do not include or provide the company EIN or any taxpayer information in the

The company’s established date is found on the “Employer Info” tab in CE. Complete research through the Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) should be used to identify any periods of time the business was functional.
Revenue (
) If the mode of contact (MOC) is “Call OK” and the contact information is available, attempt to contact the employer. If the employer is reached, see
, Contact with the Employer, to continue the veriﬁcation process. (
) If the employer cannot be reached, see IRM
, Unable to Contact the Employer. (

) Authentication of the Employer Identiﬁcation Number (EIN) is required for all calls made to the employer prior to releasing any taxpayer information. ticate the employer by verifying the following information: • EIN Reminder: If the employer questions the validity of the call or is reluctant to provide their EIN, you may provide the last digits of the EIN, then request that the employer verify ﬁrst ﬁve digits as veriﬁcation. • Business Name • The company representative’s position or relationship to the company (

) During the initial contact, keep the focus on the information necessary to the income. The employer may ask other questions not relevant to the tion of the income documents, such as: • If you are questioned on the reason for your call, explain you are reviewing income and withholding information reported on the income document. • If the employer questions why you need the income information questions whether we have the income and withholding information (Form W-
/Form
, etc.) let them know this is an accuracy check the data. (

) If the employer refuses to verify the information over the telephone, provide them other options, such as faxing us the information to assist in the tion. You should ask if they will: • Verify if the person actually worked there • Provide the employment dates if the person did work for them • Verify the ﬁgures you have, if the employer only veriﬁes that the employee worked for them but will not provide any other information, document the information in employer notes. Update Contact (CE) to disposition “Employment Only”. Reminder: Employers are not required to provide this information, but we should encourage them to do so. (
) If the employer prefers a one-time fax, take the following actions:

, etc.) let them know this is an accuracy check of the data.

Reminder: Employers are not required to provide this information, but we should encourage them to do so.
If the employer prefers a one-time fax, take the following actions:
Input contact name, secure fax number and telephone number into “Employer Keyin Information” section
Update the Status Information box to “Send Fax”, for every IDOC waiting for veriﬁcation
Do NOT change the mode of contact (MOC) to “Fax Only ”
Print the fax and fax to employer.
If the employer chooses to receive all future veriﬁcations by fax:
Revenue Protection Veriﬁcation Procedures for Individual Master File Returns 25.25.3
If an employer has a speciﬁc veriﬁcation request (requests a speciﬁc person handle the request or requests all veriﬁcations are made on a particular day).
Notate the speciﬁc request in “Employer Notes” Elevate the EIN to the lead/manager The lead/manager will change the MOC to “Hold”, and reason ment”
Note: Management will determine if the National Office Interface (NOI) needs to be updated to assign these EINs to speciﬁc examiners.

Notate CE “Permanent Instructions” if research or the employer indicates there are different numbers to call for different IDOC types. If the employer states they want to call IRS back (busy time for the employer/or they want the IRS to call them back), take the following actions: • Place the call in a callback folder/call log. • Place the employer in “Hold”, reason “Call Back IRS”. • In “Employer Notes” annotate: Call back requested (enter the • Check your call back list and return call at appropriate time. If the employer states the current year wage information is not available yet, take the following actions: • Ask when the information will be available and when we can call • Place employer in MOC “Hold”, reason “Other”. • Update calling instructions: Waiting for wages and withholding information. Input a permanent note: “Waiting for year-end • Notate the date information will be available in the “Employer Notes”. • Make a print of employer information and give to the assigned TE for follow-up. If the employer has agreed to provide the information, see IRM
, Completing the Call.
Notate CE “Permanent Instructions” if research or the employer indicates there are different numbers to call for different IDOC types.

Ask when the information will be available and when we can call back. Place employer in MOC “Hold”, reason “Other”. Update calling instructions: Waiting for wages and withholding information. Input a permanent note: “Waiting for year
end wages/WH”. Notate the date information will be available in the “Employer Notes”. Make a print of employer information and give to the assigned TE for follow
up.

Place the employer in contact and you “Hold”, reason “Call get a busy signal. Back IRS”. 3. In “Employer Notes” annotate: “Line busy”. 4. Attempt to contact the company or contact person again the same day. If you only get a busy signal, research for another contact number. 5. Attempt to call back the next day. Make a second attempt one hour later. If you only get a busy signal, research for another contact number /or call the employer to try to get another contact person. 6. If two or more contacts have been made and no number can be found or you cannot ﬁnd a good contact person, place the record in “Hold”, reason “OTHER”. Update “Employer Notes” with research information. Do not update IDOC disposi- tion.

IDOC Disposition Choices: IDOC Disposition Narrative for Disposition • 1 A one-time fax will be used for this IDOC Send Fax to obtain information from the employer. • 2 The wages and withholding amounts Incorrect $ veriﬁed by the employer do not match the ﬁgures of the IDOC. When the amounts are entered, CE will automati- cally check the ﬁgures, considering the tolerances and the literal “Incorrect $” will display. This is a ﬁnal CE disposition.
Revenue Protection Veriﬁcation Procedures for Individual Master File Returns 25.25.3

IDOC Disposition Narrative for Disposition • 3 Use this disposition when the employer Employment Only will only verify the taxpayer was employed or when the person you are verifying is the owner of the company and Forms 94X are required. Contact with the company needs to be made to ensure there is no one else that can verify the information. • The system displays the note box. Enter the employment information (for example: dates of employment, veriﬁed employment only, etc.) provided in the EFDS return section. This is a ﬁnal CE disposition. • 4 This disposition should not be used. This No Response is a ﬁnal disposition that will reﬁle the questionable return and release the refund. • 5 This disposition is used when the Not Employed employer veriﬁes that the person listed on the IDOC was not employed or had no income from that employer. This is a ﬁnal CE disposition. • 6 Employer veriﬁed the IDOC information Veriﬁed OK is correct. When this disposition is selected, actual income and actual with- holding are automatically set to match the original income and withholding amounts. IDOC(s) with the disposition of “Veriﬁed OK” cause the returns to be systemically “Reﬁled”. This is a ﬁnal CE disposition.
Employer veriﬁed the IDOC information is correct. When this disposition is selected, actual income and actual with

holding are automatically set to match the original income and withholding amounts. IDOC(s) with the disposition of “Veriﬁed OK” cause the returns to be systemically “Reﬁled”. This is a ﬁnal CE disposition.
If the caller asks other questions relating to the veriﬁcation of income, answer the questions. See possible responses to questions in the table below:

This list is not all inclusive and provides some recommended responses. If you are asked a question about veriﬁcation and you do not know the answer, tell the caller you will research the issue and call them back with an answer.

Caution: Do NOT provide tax advice. If the employer asks questions about tax issues or account matters, refer them to 800-829-1040 for individual income tax questions or 800-829-4933 for business related tax questions.
Do not contact the taxpayer to verify the income. The veriﬁcation of the income must come from the employer, or authorized representative, or online information available to IRS.

) If an EIN is in contact employer (CE), check the mode of contact (MOC) prior to making contact with the employer. If the MOC cannot be determined, contact the employer to determine the preferred MOC. (

) If the employer is willing to complete the veriﬁcation process while on the phone, update CE and return notes with any pertinent information and include the following: • Who you spoke with from the company • Title and phone number • All veriﬁcation results such as; “Not employed”, “Veriﬁed OK”, “Incorrect dollars” (include wage/withholding amounts veriﬁed), and “UTV (if unable to verify)” (

Note: When CC IRPTR data for the current year becomes available for the EIN in question, the IDOCs will be veriﬁed by CC IRPTR and MOC changed back to “Call OK”.
a. For the IDOCs that have completed veriﬁcation, update each IDOC dis- position using IRM
, Completing the Call, or IRM

, Unable to Verify (UTV) Procedures. b. Do not click “Update” until all the steps below have been completed. c. Highlight one of the IDOCs that need to stay in the “Work” tab. d. Click on the drop down arrow next to “Group Dispositions” inside the “Who at the employer gave you the information?”, and select “Hold on Rest” from the list. e. A pop up window will appear to ensure you want to take this action, on “Yes” and the window will change to the “Employer Info” tab. f. On the “Employer Info” tab, the mode of contact (MOC) will show as “Hold”. In the “Hold Information” section of the screen, select the reason “Call Back IRS” from the drop down menu and enter the date and time the hold to expire. g. Then select “Update”.
Note: The IDOCs you disposition will move into the “Completed” tab and the rest will be left under the “Work” tab.
